item.description:
"FEW recent novels have created such a literary furor in France as Louis-Ferdinand Celine's Journey to the End of the Night... One critic called it "an insult to the reader," and another referred to it as "the greatest literary discovery of the year."
--from the New York Times review, 1934

This then-shocking and revolutionary first fiction redefined the art of the novel with its acid humor, its nihilism, and its irreverent, explosive writing style, and made Celine one of France's--and literature's--most important 20th-century writers. The travails of Bardamu, the sarcastic and brilliant antihero of book move from the battlefields of World War I (complete with buffoonish officers and cowardly soldiers), to French West Africa, the United States, and back to France in a style of prose that's lyrical, hallucinatory, and hilariously scathing toward nearly everybody and everything. Yet, beneath it all one can detect a gentle core of idealism. Or can one?

"[t]errifying...—an enormously powerful and slashing, satiric, misanthropic writer. But what power of the imagination!" -- James Laughlin, founder of New Directions

"This is the novel, perhaps more than any other, that inspired me to write fiction." -- Will Self
